description: News, reaction and information about the impact of coronavirus on Jersey.
title: Coronavirus: Jersey updates 20-24 April
title_page: Coronavirus: Jersey updates 20-24 April - BBC News
maintext:
Jersey's "relatively small population" means a testing strategy based on antibody testing could be effective, Chief Minister John Le Fondre said.
The statement comes in light of recent reports calling the accuracy of the tests into question.
Senator Le Fondre said the island's small size and dedicated laboratory means they could retest people under "better controlled conditions".
He added his medical advisers were saying the tests "meet our requirements", but the report on their use was "yet to be finalised".
Asked a question about reports the government had ordered 500,000 of the tests, Health Minister Richard Renouf denied the figure and confirmed it was just 100,000 as previously indicated.
Senator Renouf said the tests were undergoing a "thorough process of validation" and the early indications were "good for the work we want them to do".
Mr Renouf added: "In so many of these medical tests you can't have 100% reliability.
"You have to work with them and understand some limitations around the percentages and if necessary test again when you need to make doubly sure."
